commit_message:
Improve validation for pseudo-folder name

At the moment, Invalid validation error occur when I specified name
of 1 or 2 letters. And we can not create it.
In addition this, it has the problem which we can create a folder
which is named empty.
So, I modified the validator to the pseudo-folder name.

Closes-Bug: #1514713

Change-Id: I4a763e49545e03829b3035b62d04ec4ff7d13b00

subject: Remove unneeded playbook vars
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-01 02:05:47.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/os-ironic-install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/b3683ded13642e21a439b1a91836aa13a7f561cb', 'message': 'Remove unneeded playbook vars

ansible_hostname is not used within any tasks and, by default, is the
same value as container_name.

ansible_ssh_host and container_address are also the same value by
default, both are assigned to hosts through the dynamic inventory
script. Additionally, overriding ansible_ssh_host through playbook vars
breaks tasks that delegate to other hosts when using Ansible 2.

Change-Id: I36a9ea861d4139b61084eb1a060907b900aa1162
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unneeded playbook vars

ansible_hostname is not used within any tasks and, by default, is the
same value as container_name.

ansible_ssh_host and container_address are also the same value by
default, both are assigned to hosts through the dynamic inventory
script. Additionally, overriding ansible_ssh_host through playbook vars
breaks tasks that delegate to other hosts when using Ansible 2.

Change-Id: I36a9ea861d4139b61084eb1a060907b900aa1162
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/30/323630/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[Ci] Make resources cleanup check voting

This patch makes tests.ci.osresources affecting job status,
so if some unexpected resources are found, then job will fail.

To make this possible, this patch adds a piece of code
which filters 'expected' remaining resources.

Also, objects.Endpoint is replaced with objects.Credential

Change-Id: Ief1413071c255e391c31ed21a478d86e2962cb60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/95/265295/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re added, removed = resources.compare(saved_list) credential = osclients.objects.Credential(**kwargs) added_, removed = resources.compare(with_list=given_list) # NOTE(amaretskiy): Some resources are expected to be remaining, so # we filter these expected changes and save them in 'filtered_added' added = [] filtered_added = [] patterns_added = [re.compile(pat) for pat in ( "^keystone role id:[\w\-]+ name:_member_$", "^(neutron|nova) security_group id:\S+ name:default tenant_id:.+")] for resource_name in added_: matched = False for pattern in patterns_added: if pattern.match(resource_name): matched = True break if matched: filtered_added.append(resource_name) else: added.append(resource_name) result = {"added": added, "removed": removed, "filtered_added": filtered_added, "has_changes": bool(added or removed)} sys.stdout.write(json.dumps(result, indent=2)) if result["has_changes"]: sys.stderr.write( "There are unexpected changes in cloud resources!\n") return 1
deleted_lines: changes = resources.compare(saved_list) has_changed = any(changes) removed, added = changes credential = osclients.objects.Endpoint(**kwargs) changes = resources.compare(with_list=given_list) removed, added = changes sys.stdout.write( json.dumps({"removed": removed, "added": added}, indent=2)) if any(changes): return 0 # `1' will fail gate job

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-31 15:11:48.000000000', 'files': ['fuelweb_test/tests/test_states_unlock_settings_tab.py', 'fuelweb_test/models/fuel_web_client.py', 'fuelweb_test/models/nailgun_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa/commit/e3f326c2092c23ffb82905e67b6d2c5d711d414f', 'message': 'Test for unlock_settings_tab feature.

This test checkes that feature "unlock settings"  wiil be working
with different cluster and network settings which
changing during deployment.

        Scenario:
            1. Create cluster
            2. Download default cluster settings
            3. Create custom_config and upload it to cluster
            4. Add 3 nodes with controller role and 2 nodes with compute role
            5. Deploy the cluster
            6. Stop deployment process
            7. Get current settings
            8. Change and save them (that means settings are unlocked)
            9. Redeploy cluster via api
            10. Get cluster and network settings via api (api load deployed)
            11. Compare settings from step 8 and 10 (them must be equal)
            12. Get default settings via api (load defaults)
            13. Compare settings from step 2 and 13 (them must be equal)
            14. Redeploy cluster
            15. Stop deployment process
            16. Redeploy cluster
            17. Run OSTF

Change-Id: Ia72da06a9ebb982d5c22a98bfe162623073aeed9
(cherry picked from commit a8b1cb82758b0028ecdcb173182e5fc608d29dad)
'}]
commit_message:
Test for unlock_settings_tab feature.

This test checkes that feature "unlock settings"  wiil be working
with different cluster and network settings which
changing during deployment.

        Scenario:
            1. Create cluster
            2. Download default cluster settings
            3. Create custom_config and upload it to cluster
            4. Add 3 nodes with controller role and 2 nodes with compute role
            5. Deploy the cluster
            6. Stop deployment process
            7. Get current settings
            8. Change and save them (that means settings are unlocked)
            9. Redeploy cluster via api
            10. Get cluster and network settings via api (api load deployed)
            11. Compare settings from step 8 and 10 (them must be equal)
            12. Get default settings via api (load defaults)
            13. Compare settings from step 2 and 13 (them must be equal)
            14. Redeploy cluster
            15. Stop deployment process
            16. Redeploy cluster
            17. Run OSTF

Change-Id: Ia72da06a9ebb982d5c22a98bfe162623073aeed9
(cherry picked from commit a8b1cb82758b0028ecdcb173182e5fc608d29dad)

commit_message:
Support for chrony NTP

- added NtpChronyd
- BaseNtp and its sub-classes were refactored
- simplified AbstractNtp API
- updated unit tests

Closes-Bug: #1583190

commit_message:
Fix support for changing settings for some of the services

Allow a user to change particular openstack and misc
services configuration.

Supports:
  ceilometer
  cinder
  glance
  haproxy
  heat
  mysql
  rabbitmq

DocImpact

Closes-bug: #1580522

Change-Id: I2933846f78c94933419d4dfd3dfbe49178172ff9

subject: Allow a user to run dry-run deployment
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-31 10:16:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/6eb13f38553320af5721cad07e75369f79e46236', 'message': "Allow a user to run dry-run deployment

Now following handlers:

     /clusters/:cluster_id/changes/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/changes/redeploy/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/deploy/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/deploy_tasks/

?dry_run=1 that is telling Astute not to run cluster executionat all.

Dry run assumes that it does not actually affect
cluster status regardless of their result.

Also, remove redundant update of nodes statuses to 'deploying'
within OpenStackConfigManager and DeploymentTaskManager as it should be
done by receiever.

Do not set cluster status to 'deployment' for these nodes in order to
retain its real status

Modify stop deployment tests to move failing stop deployment for already
deployed clusters to another test class. Since 9.0 we can run stop
deployment for new clusters.

Change-Id: I374fc86b63af64411d4a5ca45ff6c3680cb44897

commit_message:
Allow a user to run dry-run deployment

Now following handlers:

     /clusters/:cluster_id/changes/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/changes/redeploy/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/deploy/
     /clusters/:cluster_id/deploy_tasks/

?dry_run=1 that is telling Astute not to run cluster executionat all.

Dry run assumes that it does not actually affect
cluster status regardless of their result.

Also, remove redundant update of nodes statuses to 'deploying'
within OpenStackConfigManager and DeploymentTaskManager as it should be
done by receiever.

Do not set cluster status to 'deployment' for these nodes in order to
retain its real status

Modify stop deployment tests to move failing stop deployment for already
deployed clusters to another test class. Since 9.0 we can run stop
deployment for new clusters.

Change-Id: I374fc86b63af64411d4a5ca45ff6c3680cb44897
Partial-bug: #1569839

added_lines: A high-availability (HA) deployment of Swift requires that multiple proxy servers are deployed and requests are load-balanced between them. Each proxy server instance is stateless and able to respond to requests for the entire cluster.

commit_message:
Fix issue with messaging

Use version 5.0.0 or above of oslo.messaging to avoid issue of locally
queuing of RPC requests.

Change-Id: I6d43ebe59521f5e577269270a2b784736d7af4f1
Closes-Bug: #1580977

commit_message:
Adding audit rule for SELinux policy modifications

This patch fixes the auditd rules template so that AppArmor and SELinux
policy modifications are logged, depending on which Linux distribution
is in use. The security_audit_apparmor_changes variable has been renamed
to security_audit_mac_changes to be more generic.

Documentation updates and a release note are included.

Closes-bug: 1584187

Change-Id: I0955e2cb8a05af4afd36aaca518322a9df6d1ff7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/38/319438/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: security_audit_mac_changes: yes # V-38541

commit_message:
Provide type for boolean module parameters

Instead of inserting 'True' and 'False' into Ansible's BOOLEANS
constants, designate the parameters as a 'bool' type.
ansible.module_utils.basic will downcase and handle ensuring the
variables are cast to booleans.

Change-Id: I2fc70a90df5cca76b49fc21adee59350173157d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins refs/changes/88/323588/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: type='bool',
deleted_lines: # Add in python True False BOOLEANS.extend(['False', 'True']) BOOLEANS_TRUE.append('True') BOOLEANS_FALSE.append('False') choices=BOOLEANS, is_metal = module.params.get('is_metal') if is_metal in BOOLEANS_TRUE: module.params['is_metal'] = True else: module.params['is_metal'] = False

commit_message:
Corrected xml generation for external snapshots

This patch corrects external snapshot XML generation to get XML
according to the libvirt documentation.
It lets use external snapshot functionality with environments
that have dots in their names. Without this change system tests
fail during snapshot creation.

Tests are modified to reflect changes made in libvirt xml builder
code base as well.

Change-Id: I8c12430047eeed439e644638b458bcec3b684900
Closes-Bug: #1583139

commit_message:
Fix live migration with shared storage

At the moment, when live migration is requested, we attempt to
copy the instance dvd disks and log files to the remote location,
other instance files being transparently copied by Hyper-V.

The issue is that we don't check whether shared storage is being
used, in which case this will fail.

This change adds this check.

Closes-Bug: #1565895

Change-Id: Ib646c90c830a1cd0e5401d14c6d400226b034f73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv refs/changes/65/322065/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_remote_instances_dir_shared(self, dest): # Checks if the instances dir from a remote host points # to the same storage location as the local instances dir. local_inst_dir = self.get_instances_dir() remote_inst_dir = self.get_instances_dir(dest) return check_dirs_shared_storage(local_inst_dir, remote_inst_dir)

commit_message:
Correct nova admin endpoint version

In Liberty the primary nova endpoints changed to v2.1, but the group_var
for the nova admin endpoint was not changed appropriately.

This patch corrects the endpoint version.

Change-Id: If0ac2c117f36a7dada02991fbf2b6447c71f7df1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/21/323321/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-31 10:14:31.000000000', 'files': ['rally/cli/commands/verify.py', 'tests/unit/cli/commands/test_verify.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/051a8c1c6fc9d959d50eea2d78dff9dcf74ec3c2', 'message': 'verify: start and import_results always print uuid

Previously UUID of verifications that ware created by these commands

commit_message:
verify: start and import_results always print uuid

Previously UUID of verifications that ware created by these commands
with --no-use were not printed to stdout. It unnecessarily force
users to stop using --no-use or to search the UUID in rally.log or
in "rally verify list".

With this change, a line "Verification UUID: <UUID>" will always
appear in output of these command, regardless of weather if --no-use
is specified. It allows users to extract UUID by a relatively simple
filter such as "| grep -Po '(?<=^Verification UUID: ).*$'".

Closes-bug: 1587034
Change-Id: I4afbaf82472068ccf9b9c074d1d94a36fcbf246a

commit_message:
[ops] Improves the procedure workflow

Addresses the comments to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/323349

* s/utilizing/using
* Replaces "next", "then", "finally", etc., with the numbered list.

Change-Id: Iaf2b63e44cc3abd61f69298b7dbe49885b0b5336
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/323691/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If you need to reboot a compute node due to planned maintenance, such as a software or hardware upgrade, perform the following steps: #. Disable scheduling of new VMs to the node, optionally providing a reason comment: .. code-block:: console # nova service-disable --reason maintenance c01.example.com nova-compute #. Verify that all hosted instances have been moved off the node: * If your cloud is using a shared storage: #. Get a list of instances that need to be moved: .. code-block:: console # nova list --host c01.example.com --all-tenants #. Migrate all instances one by one: .. code-block:: console # nova live-migration <uuid> c02.example.com * If your cloud is not using a shared storage, run: .. code-block:: console # nova live-migration --block-migrate <uuid> c02.example.com #. Stop the ``nova-compute`` service: .. code-block:: console # stop nova-compute If you use a configuration-management system, such as Puppet, that ensures the ``nova-compute`` service is always running, you can temporarily move the ``init`` files: .. code-block:: console # mkdir /root/tmp # mv /etc/init/nova-compute.conf /root/tmp # mv /etc/init.d/nova-compute /root/tmp #. Shut down your compute node, perform the maintenance, and turn the node back on. #. Start the ``nova-compute`` service: .. code-block:: console # start nova-compute You can re-enable the ``nova-compute`` service by undoing the commands: .. code-block:: console # mv /root/tmp/nova-compute.conf /etc/init # mv /root/tmp/nova-compute /etc/init.d/ #. Enable scheduling of VMs to the node: .. code-block:: console # nova service-enable c01.example.com nova-compute #. Optionally, migrate the instances back to their original compute node.stored on it.
deleted_lines: If you need to reboot a compute node due to planned maintenance (such as a software or hardware upgrade), first disable scheduling of new VMs to the node, optionally providing a reason comment: .. code-block:: console # nova service-disable --reason maintenance c01.example.com nova-compute Next, ensure that all hosted instances have been moved off the node. If your cloud is utilizing shared storage, use the :command:`nova live-migration` command. First, get a list of instances that need to be moved: .. code-block:: console # nova list --host c01.example.com --all-tenants Next, migrate them one by one: .. code-block:: console # nova live-migration <uuid> c02.example.com If you are not using shared storage, you can use the :option:`--block-migrate` option: .. code-block:: console # nova live-migration --block-migrate <uuid> c02.example.com After you have migrated all instances, ensure that the ``nova-compute`` service has stopped: .. code-block:: console # stop nova-compute If you use a configuration-management system, such as Puppet, that ensures the ``nova-compute`` service is always running, you can temporarily move the ``init`` files: .. code-block:: console # mkdir /root/tmp # mv /etc/init/nova-compute.conf /root/tmp # mv /etc/init.d/nova-compute /root/tmp Next, shut down your compute node, perform your maintenance, and turn the node back on. You can reenable the ``nova-compute`` service by undoing the previous commands: .. code-block:: console # mv /root/tmp/nova-compute.conf /etc/init # mv /root/tmp/nova-compute /etc/init.d/ Then start the ``nova-compute`` service: .. code-block:: console # start nova-compute Finally, enable scheduling of VMs to the node: .. code-block:: console # nova service-enable c01.example.com nova-compute You can now optionally migrate the instances back to their original compute node.stored on it.

commit_message:
Use new parameter for Glance with VMware backend

- Remove deprecated vcenter_datacenter
  and vcenter_datastore parameters
- Use new vcenter_datastores parameter
- Update noop tests

Support of new parameters merged in

subject: Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-21 16:31:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/f0860fcf314653ecf53593969fc875b1d75e1805', 'message': 'Fall back from ATA erase to shredding

Presently the method that handles ATA erasure operations raises
an exception when conditions such as the security settings of the
drive have been locked.

The caller receives the raised exception, but has no handling
of it and as such cleaning is aborted as the host results in a
"clean failed" state.

Instead of allowing the failure to abort the operation, we
should ideally log that this occured and fall back to the
default cleaning method.

Closes-Bug: #1536695
Change-Id: I88edd9477f4f05aa55b2fe8efa4bbff1c5573bb1

commit_message:
Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding

Presently should the ATA erasure operation fails, IPA halts the
cleaning process and the node goes to CLEANFAIL state as a result.

This failure could be the result of a previous cleaning failure
that left drive security enabled, for which code has been added
in an attempt to address this case by attempting to unlock the
the drive.

In the event that an operator wishes to automatically fallback to
disk scrubbing operations, the capability has been added through
a driver_internal_info field "agent_continue_if_ata_erase_failed"
that can be set to True, however defaults to False keeping the
same behavior that IPA presently exhibits in the event of ATA
erase operations failing.

Partial-Bug: #1536695
Change-Id: I88edd9477f4f05aa55b2fe8efa4bbff1c5573bb1

added_lines: @mock.patch.object(hardware.GenericHardwareManager, '_shred_block_device') def test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled( self, mocked_execute, mock_shred): self.hardware.erase_block_device(self.node, block_device) self.assertTrue(mock_shred.called) @mock.patch.object(hardware.GenericHardwareManager, '_shred_block_device') def test_erase_block_device_ata_frozen(self, mocked_execute, mock_shred): self.hardware.erase_block_device(self.node, block_device) # Ensure that we falled back to shred self.assertTrue(mock_shred.called) @mock.patch.object(hardware.GenericHardwareManager, '_shred_block_device') def test_erase_block_device_ata_failed(self, mocked_execute, mock_shred): self.hardware.erase_block_device(self.node, block_device) # Ensure that we falled back to shred. self.assertTrue(mock_shred.called)
deleted_lines: def test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled(self, mocked_execute): self.assertRaises(errors.BlockDeviceEraseError, self.hardware.erase_block_device, self.node, block_device) def test_erase_block_device_ata_frozen(self, mocked_execute): self.assertRaises(errors.BlockDeviceEraseError, self.hardware.erase_block_device, self.node, block_device) def test_erase_block_device_ata_failed(self, mocked_execute): self.assertRaises(errors.BlockDeviceEraseError, self.hardware.erase_block_device, self.node, block_device)

"}, {'number': 35, 'created': '2016-05-26 13:19:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/8f79f9058df72e895ad340fa5edaa796152639d7', 'message': "Refactor Mistral Engine

* Introduced class hierarchies Task and Action used by Mistral engine.
  Note: Action here is a different than executor Action and represents
  rather actions of different types: regular python action, ad-hoc
  action and workflow action (since for task action and workflow are
  polymorphic)
* Refactored task_handler.py and action_handler.py with Task and Action
  hierarchies
* Rebuilt a chain call so that the entire action processing would look
  like a chain of calls Action -> Task -> Workflow where each level
  knows only about the next level and can influence it (e.g. if adhoc
  action has failed due to YAQL error in 'output' transformer action
  itself fails its task)
* Refactored policies according to new object model
* Fixed some of the tests to match the idea of having two types of
  exceptions, MistralException and MistralError, where the latter
  is considered either a harsh environmental problem or a logical
  issue in the system itself so that it must not be handled anywhere
  in the code

TODO(in subsequent patches):
 * Refactor WithItemsTask w/o using with_items.py
 * Remove DB transaction in Scheduler when making a delayed call,
   helper policy methods like 'continue_workflow'
 * Refactor policies test so that workflow definitions live right
   in test methods
 * Refactor workflow_handler with Workflow abstraction
 * Get rid of RunExistingTask workflow command, it should be just
   one command with various properties
 * Refactor resume and rerun with Task abstraction (same way as
   other methods, e.g. on_action_complete())
 * Add error handling to all required places such as
   task_handler.continue_task()
 * More tests for error handling

Implements: blueprint mistral-engine-error-handling
Implements: blueprint mistral-action-result-processing-pipeline
Implements: blueprint mistral-refactor-task-handler

Change-Id: I0668e695c60dde31efc690563fc891387d44d6ba

commit_message:
Refactor Mistral Engine

* Introduced class hierarchies Task and Action used by Mistral engine.
  Note: Action here is a different than executor Action and represents
  rather actions of different types: regular python action, ad-hoc
  action and workflow action (since for task action and workflow are
  polymorphic)
* Refactored task_handler.py and action_handler.py with Task and Action
  hierarchies
* Rebuilt a chain call so that the entire action processing would look
  like a chain of calls Action -> Task -> Workflow where each level
  knows only about the next level and can influence it (e.g. if adhoc
  action has failed due to YAQL error in 'output' transformer action
  itself fails its task)
* Refactored policies according to new object model
* Fixed some of the tests to match the idea of having two types of
  exceptions, MistralException and MistralError, where the latter
  is considered either a harsh environmental problem or a logical
  issue in the system itself so that it must not be handled anywhere
  in the code

TODO(in subsequent patches):
 * Refactor WithItemsTask w/o using with_items.py
 * Remove DB transaction in Scheduler when making a delayed call,
   helper policy methods like 'continue_workflow'
 * Refactor policies test so that workflow definitions live right
   in test methods
 * Refactor workflow_handler with Workflow abstraction
 * Get rid of RunExistingTask workflow command, it should be just
   one command with various properties
 * Refactor resume and rerun with Task abstraction (same way as
   other methods, e.g. on_action_complete())
 * Add error handling to all required places such as
   task_handler.continue_task()
 * More tests for error handling

P.S. This patch is very big but it was nearly impossible to split
it into multiple smaller patches just because how entangled everything
was in Mistral Engine.

Partially implements: blueprint mistral-engine-error-handling
Implements: blueprint mistral-action-result-processing-pipeline
Implements: blueprint mistral-refactor-task-handler
Closes-Bug: #1568909

Change-Id: I0668e695c60dde31efc690563fc891387d44d6ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/79/317879/42 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with db_api.transaction(): # The new workflow execution will be in an IDLE # state on initial record creation. wf_ex_id, wf_spec = wf_ex_service.create_workflow_execution( wf_identifier, wf_input, description, params ) # TODO(rakhmerov): No need to get it again, method # create_workflow_execution() should return an object. wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex_id) wf_handler.set_execution_state(wf_ex, states.RUNNING) wf_ctrl = wf_base.get_controller(wf_ex, wf_spec) self._dispatch_workflow_commands( wf_ex, wf_ctrl.continue_workflow(), wf_spec return wf_ex.get_clone() action_def = action_handler.get_action_definition(action_name) # TODO(rakhmerov): This error handling should be hidden in # task_handler and it seems like it should know about workflow # controller. # TODO(rakhmerov): This should be hidden in task_handler. # TODO(rakhmerov): Need to move this method to workflow_handler. with db_api.transaction(): action_ex = db_api.get_action_execution(action_ex_id) action_handler.on_action_complete(action_ex, result) # If this action doesn't belong to any tasks, no need to continue. if not action_ex.task_execution: action_ex.get_clone() wf_ex_id = action_ex.task_execution.workflow_execution_id wf_ex = wf_handler.lock_workflow_execution(wf_ex_id) wf_spec = spec_parser.get_workflow_spec(wf_ex.spec) task_ex = task_handler.on_action_complete(action_ex) # If workflow is on pause or completed then there's no # need to continue workflow. if states.is_paused_or_completed(wf_ex.state): self._on_task_state_change(task_ex, wf_ex, wf_spec) return action_ex.get_clone() # TODO(rakhmerov): Add error handling. # TODO(akhmerov): Seems like it should be in workflow handler as well. elif isinstance(cmd, (commands.RunTask, commands.RunExistingTask)): task_ex = task_handler.run_task(cmd, wf_spec) # TODO(rakhmerov): This check shouldn't be here too, it should # be chained from task_handler to workflow_handler. # TODO(rakhmerov): All these checks should be in workflow # handler.

LOG.error( 'Failed to handle action execution result [id=%s]: %s\n%s', action_ex_id, e, traceback.format_exc() ) # If an exception was thrown after we got the wf_ex_id if wf_ex_id: self._fail_workflow(wf_ex_id, e) raise e # TODO(rakhmerov): Add YAQL error handling. elif isinstance(cmd, commands.RunTask): task_ex = task_handler.run_new_task(cmd, wf_spec) if task_ex.state == states.ERROR: wf_handler.fail_workflow( wf_ex, 'Failed to start task [task_ex=%s]: %s' % (task_ex, task_ex.state_info) ) elif isinstance(cmd, commands.RunExistingTask): task_ex = task_handler.run_existing_task( cmd.task_ex.id, reset=cmd.reset )

commit_message:
Fix py3 issue in functional tests

Change expected result bytes -> string, requests returns
result as string, which is unicode in py3.

Change-Id: I4fe6792303d9f126173045da038dcaf518a5bcc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/21/321521/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-17 17:05:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/c6b2dcd08e299488eb173fce5d4454cb715aabe1', 'message': "Add *args, **kwargs to ModalBackdropMixin's init method

Change-Id: I6155476738021b784ef7e643c968f1d784b15906
Closes-Bug: #1582816
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-18 13:31:39.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/forms/views.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/bb1547c8abcc0d0d3dc4a3199e8e8bd1b5527c12', 'message': "Add *args, **kwargs to ModalBackdropMixin's init method

Before this change ModalBackdropMixin called super(...).__init__()
without arguments. This imposed restrictions on what classes this
mixin could have been mixed into, i.e. only classes, that do not accept
any parameters.
This proved to be a problem for murano-dashboard, since it uses this
mixin (indirectly through ModalFormMixin) and mixes it into a class,
that accepts parameters to it's init method.
This change allows to use ModalBackdropMixin with classes that have
init methods with parameters.

Change-Id: I6155476738021b784ef7e643c968f1d784b15906
Closes-Bug: #1582816
"}]
commit_message:
Add *args, **kwargs to ModalBackdropMixin's init method

Before this change ModalBackdropMixin called super(...).__init__()
without arguments. This imposed restrictions on what classes this
mixin could have been mixed into, i.e. only classes, that do not accept
any parameters.
This proved to be a problem for murano-dashboard, since it uses this
mixin (indirectly through ModalFormMixin) and mixes it into a class,
that accepts parameters to it's init method.
This change allows to use ModalBackdropMixin with classes that have
init methods with parameters.

Change-Id: I6155476738021b784ef7e643c968f1d784b15906
Closes-Bug: #1582816
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/28/317628/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ModalBackdropMixin, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Add test for ironic task idempotency

This testgroup should be run with this parameters:
export SLAVE_NODE_MEMORY=4096
export IRONIC_ENABLED=true
export IRONIC_NODES_COUNT=1
export ENV_SLAVE_LOGIN=root
export ENV_SLAVE_PASSWORD=r00tme

Change-Id: I168032ee155fdab395d31058029e962593480618
Implements: blueprint test-granular-task-idempotency

commit_message:
Allow use floating IP to specify a resource

Allowing user to use both floating IP address and floating IP id to
specify a floating IP resource.

Closes-bug: #1461998

Change-Id: I1ad25ce02e76e0ec299d502e93d164e4c766c0bd

commit_message:
Add '--router:external' option to 'net-create'

Add '--router:external' option to 'net-create'.
The option '--router:external' requests a boolean argument
to keep backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I79afadadc160552abaa8db41ec3ae01811e38616

commit_message:
Pass environment variables of proxy to tox

When a development environment is under a proxy, tox is failed
even if environment variables of the proxy are set. This is a
new feature above tox 2.0, you can check it from [1].

This patch fix this problem.

[1]. https://tox.readthedocs.org/en/latest/example/basic.html#passing-down-environment-variables

Change-Id: I8b963e85e5ba15e0d10e7ab1ec722433a9615b3a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/36/266636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: passenv = http_proxy HTTP_PROXY https_proxy HTTPS_PROXY no_proxy NO_PROXY

only import needed module. When from module import * is used, you are

commit_message:
Avoid using wildcard (*) imports

In general, import statements should be as specific as possible
and only import needed module. When from module import * is used,
you are implicitly loading all locals of the imported module into
and over the importing module. This has two disadvantages: first,
you might unintentionally overload already imported objects. Second,
it becomes difficult to detect undefined names in the program that
imported the module.

Change-Id: I65f8b3f40f5a89232144d3c399a4aa3bd13ee62c
Closes-Bug: #1535787
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/73/269973/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * [N355] - Ensure that wildcard (*) imports are not used

commit_message:
[ops-guide] Clarify maintenance mode for computes

The doc section does not currently highlight the fact that VMs can
still be scheduled to the compute node which is about to be shut off
for maintenance, unless nova-compute service is explicitly disabled
in Nova. Without this migration of workloads may never complete.

Closes-Bug: #1587450

Change-Id: I36697bb1556d96c31171fcc55d988a5b8bcfa1cd

commit_message:
Use CONF.network.tenant_network_cidr instead of hardcode cidr

There is a config option in neutron to allow user give the cidr
block to allocate tenant ipv4 subnets from. Nova test should use
it when create network too.

Change-Id: I735a224d75a9b185016ed0d0c881611d02082a6c

commit_message:
Use CONF.network.floating_network_name to create floating IP

Currently, tempest give no pool infomation when creating floating IP,
it relys on nova-api service to find default_floating_pool from nova.conf.
When default_floating_pool in nova.conf is missing, The test will fail.

Change-Id: I8daae3f2c980cee1b10652bcdaf7eaf52cc33f0a

commit_message:
Moving authentication from keystoneclient to keystoneauth

Current code uses keystoneclient for the auth plugins. This
change will update it to use keystoneauth.

Change-Id: Ie374489332f72a46b4d6fe01f4b75fb48ce6a3e5

Change-Id: Icba6929d32ae2cc47ccb776e24bc8beac6b717d2

added_lines: def list_baymodels(self, detail=False): """List Magnum baymodels. :param bool normalize: Flag to control dict normalization :returns: a list of dicts containing the baymodel details. :raises: ``OpenStackCloudException``: if something goes wrong during the openstack API call. """ try: baymodels = self.manager.submitTask(_tasks.BaymodelList(detail=detail)) except Exception as e: self.log.debug("Failed to list baymodels", exc_info=True) raise OpenStackCloudException(str(e)) return baymodels

commit_message:
[user-guide] Update swift manage access section

Updated swift manage access section in user-guide with
correct container ACL syntax and examples.

Change-Id: I4930d49db4a494ebd9137d1110286b54334efbda
Closes-Bug: 1586699
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/98/323498/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Read ACL for containers. ``.r:*`` (a request with any HTTP referer header can read) ``.r:*,.rlistings`` (a request with any HTTP referer header can read and list container contents) ``.r:openstack.example.com,.r:swift.example.com,.r:storage.example.com`` (list of specific HTTP referer headers permitted to read) ``.r:*,.r:-openstack.example.com,.r:-swift.example.com,.r:-storage.example.com`` (list of specific HTTP referer headers denied read) ``project1:*`` (all users residing in project1 can read) ``project1:user1`` (user1 from project1 can read) ``project1:user1,project1:user2,project3:*,project4:user1`` (list of specific users permitted to read) Write ACL for containers. ``project1:*`` (all users residing in project1 can write) ``project1:user1`` (user1 from project1 can write) ``project1:user1,project1:user2,project3:*,project4:user1`` (list of specific users permitted to write) Note: To successfully write to a container, a user must have read privileges (in addition to write) on the container. For all aforementioned read/write ACL examples, one can replace the project/user name with project/user UUID, i.e. ``<project_uuid>:<user_uuid>``. If using multiple keystone domains, UUID format is required.
deleted_lines: Read ACL for containers. Quick summary of ACL syntax: ``.r:*``, ``.r:-.example.com``, ``.r:www.example.com``, ``account1``, ``account2:user2`` Write ACL for containers. Quick summary of ACL syntax: account1 account2:user2

commit_message:
Live Migration of Rescued Instances

When an instance is rescued the libvirt driver creates a file in the.
instance directory that contains the original instance xml. This file
is used when unrescuing the instance to revert to the original disk
configuration. However, this file is not necessary to restore the
instance's original configuration. Furthermore the reliance on this
file means we currently cannot live migrate a rescued instance.  Thus
it is proposed that we do not create this file during the rescue
operation and rebuild the instance's original xml file from the
database when we unrescue it.

APIImpact
Change-Id: Id3a055f00c3f8ef006911e2523c8d284f449b524
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/31/307131/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ ============================================================ Blueprint:https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-migrate-rescued-instances When an instance is rescued the libvirt driver creates a file in the. instance directory that contains the original instance xml. This file is used when unrescuing the instance to revert to the original disk configuration. However, this file is not necessary to restore the instance's original configuration. Furthermore the reliance on this file means we currently cannot live migrate a rescued instance. Thus it is proposed that we do not create this file during the rescue operation and rebuild the instance's original xml file from the database when we unrescue it. Problem description =================== At present operators cannot live migrate rescued instances. Use Cases ---------- As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I like to live migrations all instances on a node in order to perform maintenance. Proposed change =============== The rescue method of the libvirt driver object will be changed to remove the generation of an unrescue.xml file. The unrescue method will be amended to remove the attempt to read the unrescue.xml file and delete the libvirt.xml file. The unrescue method will use the _get_guest_xml to create the xml before destroying and creating the instance as at present. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is not doing this, leaving it up to operators to ask the user to unrescue their instance so it can be migrated. Another option is to write the original libvirt xml to the database during the rescue operation so that it can be retrieved by the target compute node during unrescue. However this unnecessary and would require a database schema change to add a table to store this information (no existing suitable table has a field big enough to accommodate the xml text). Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User attemting to unrescue an instance whilst a migration was in progress.would be prevented from doing so until the migoration was complete. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Paul Carlton (irc: paul-carlton2) Other assignees: None Work Items ---------- * Change libvirt driver rescue and unrescue functions. * Change compute manager unrescue to pass context object to virt/driver unrescue method and change implementations of virt/driver unrescue to accept context parameter. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added as required. Documentation Impact ==================== New API needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html * nova.compute.api documentation http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.compute.api.html References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Make checks before live-migration async

APIImpact

bp: async-live-migration-rest-check

Change-Id: I07d0581cc7db9b5fdc34073625a548d1f42f8633
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/16/320416/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================= Make checks before live-migration async ======================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/async-live-migration-rest-check Existing live-migration operation, provided by nova is quite complex thing. Nova made verification of the env before acception and triggering live-migration. While this validation is required, it's done in synchronious way, and is quite complex by itself, from api service request is send over RPC call to conductor, which triggers 2 more rpc calls to compute, and only if everything is OK, request triggers rpc cast to compute, to start process, and REST API layer response with 202. Problem description =================== Existing workflow is complex, and leaves space for timeouts, and also blocks HTTP request, which in general is bad. Use Cases --------- From the user's point Nova will respond faster for it's live-migration request, forcing operators to check current status with `instance-actions`. Proposed change =============== Instead of doing all check in blocking way this spec propose to record conductor's method with `wrap_instance_event` so it will be possible to check live-migration status. Nova API should send rpc cast to conductor, so response will be immediately send to operator. Alternatives ------------ Leave things as is. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- As this change makes all check to be done in background, REST API will stop to response with `badRequest(400)`. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Users should check live-migration status, using `instance-actions` operation. Performance Impact ------------------ Getting rid of blocking rest/rpc request will slightly improve overall performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tdurakov Other contributors: rpodolyaka Work Items ---------- * Add `wrap_instance_event` decorator to conductor's methods * Make live-migration checks nonblocking * Bump Nova REST API version. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Test for checking that conductor's part of live-migration is recorded by instance-actions should be added to tempest. Documentation Impact ==================== As this change changes workflow, docs should be updated. It's needed to highlight to the end user that it's required to check live-migration process over `instance-actions`. References ========== * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/314932/ - PoC History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Automatic Live Migration Completion

Spec to automate the use of various libvirt/qemu
features to complete live migrations when instance
memory access rate is high.

Change-Id: Id0b334ba8c4d97b3eaa58a6fe3b1242560567853
Blueprint: auto-live-migration-completion
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/61/306561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Automate Live Migration Completion Strategies ============================================================ Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/auto-live-migration-completion There are number of strategies which can be used to help a live migration operation complete. It is desirable to automate the use of these based on how important it is to the operator that the live migration completes and the availability profile[1]_ of the instance being migrated. Problem description =================== When an operator performs a live migration they need to monitor it to ensure it is making progress and take actions to help it complete. This is labor intensive and this expensive in terms of cloud operating costs. It would be preferable if the live migration process could automatically take action to try and complete the migration. Use Cases ---------- As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I like live migrations to, as far as possible, progress to completion without operator intervention. Proposed change =============== A new parameter will be added to the live migration API to specify the importance of the live migration operation. This will accept values of 'low', 'medium' or 'high' defaulting to 'medium' if omitted. The live migration processing will use this importance setting as well as the instance's availability profile settings[1]_ to determine what strategies to employ if the live migration is struggling to complete due to the instance's memory access or disk I/O rates. The options available are as follows: Auto-converge. This feature provides a method for slowing down guest execution speed in order to allow the live migration to copy dirty memory pages to the target and complete the migration. It has to be enabled prior to the start of a live migration operation. If enabled the live migration process will make a first pass of copying all memory pages to the target then incrementally decrease the instances CPU speed until the migration is completed. By default it will initially decrease the CPU speed by 20% then reduce it by further increments of 10% until the instance is effectively paused. The initial decrease and increment size can be adjusted during the live migration process via the libvirt API. Post-Copy If enabled the live migration process will make a first pass of copying all memory pages to the target then it will make the instance on the target active and start pulling memory pages that have not yet been updated on the target from the source as they are accessed. There are two modes this can operate in. It can enabled so libvirt/qemu decide when to switch the instance to the target and start doing post copying. Alternatively it can be enabled but not switch the instance to the target unless a libvirt API called is performed to tell it to switch. The use of Post-Copy has an impact on instance performance after the switch to post copying mode. Also, once in post copy mode if the migration processing fails then the instance will crash and need to be rebooted. Maximum Downtime Setting In order to perform the switch over from the source to target instances the live migration process needs to pause the instance for a short period. The default value is 500 milliseconds but this can be adjusted during the live migration process via a libvirt API call. Increasing this value may enable the migration to complete. Force-Complete If the migration is not making progress the instance can be suspended to allow the migration to complete. It will be automatically resumed when the migration completes and it switches to the target. Using the live migration importance level and instance availability profile settings the live migration processing will be initiated and managed in a manner designed to meet the needs of the cloud operator to complete the migration task and the availability requirements of the instance owner. The relevant instance availability setting are importance=<'cattle', 'pet', 'panda'> down_time_max=<max down time in seconds> cpu_throttling_max=<max cpu throttling percentage> tolerate_suspend=<boolean> The following rules will be applied when determining what actions to take to complete a live migration process which is struggling to do so due to the instance's memory access rate. Generate a value based on the migration importance and instance importance as follows: Migration importance Low = 0 Migration importance Medium = 10 Migration importance High = 25 Instance importance Cattle = 25 Instance importance Pet = 15 Instance importance Panda = 0 Sum the two numbers so: High + Cattle = 50 High + Pet = 40 Medium + Cattle = 35 High + Panda = 25 Medium + Pet = 25 Low + Cattle = 25 Low + Pet = 15 Medium + Panda = 10 Low + Panda = 0 Use this 'aggression' value to determine which features to employ to complete the migration. The aggression value needs to be equal to or greater than the values below for the respective feature to be used. Force-Complete = 40 Auto-Converge = 35 Post-Copy = 25 Max-Downtime = 15 However apply the following rule as well: Only enable auto-converge if the instance's cpu_throttling_max is greater than 30, i.e. they can tolerate less than 70% CPU speed. If the instance's down_time_max is non zero then if the migration is not completing set the maximum downtime setting to this value (*1000 for milliseconds). If tolerate_suspend is false do not use Force-Complete. It is proposed that post copy be enabled in manual mode, i.e. it will only start performing post copy if an API call is performed to initiate it. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is not doing this, leaving it up to operators to manage live migrations. An alternative would be to either enable or disable migration options (such as post copy, auto-converge and the maximum down time setting) via nova configuration flags. Enabling these options globally could lead to customer complaints about instance performance and availability because use of these features can potentially have a significant impact on instance performance. Another approach would to be to provide the operator with APIs so they could select and tune these setting before and during live migrations. However it is not desirable to expose driver specifics to Nova API. Data model impact ----------------- Add a column to migrations table called 'importance'. This will hold a value of 'low', 'medium' or 'high', with a default value of 'medium'. `importance` enum('low','medium','high') DEFAULT 'medium' REST API impact --------------- To be added in a new microversion. * Add an additional field to live migration request parameters called importance. This field will be optional and if not present the importance will be set to 'medium'. `POST /v2.1/​{tenant_id}​/servers/​{server_id}​/action` Body:: { "os-migrateLive": { "importance": “high”, } } Normal http response code: `202 Accepted` No response body is needed Expected error http response code: `404 Not Found` - the instance does not exist Expected error http response code: `403 Forbidden` - Policy violation if the caller is not an administrator Expected error http response code: `400 Bad Request` - the instance state is is not valid for live-migration operation or the importance option value is invalid Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- A new optional parameter called 'importance' will be added to python-novaclient live-migration and host-evacuate-live, e.g. nova live-migration --importance <importance> Where <importance> is 'low', 'medium' or 'high'. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Paul Carlton (irc: paul-carlton2) Other assignees: None Work Items ---------- * Nova API changes for os-live-migration and os-host-evacuate-live. * python-novaclient 'live-migration and host-evacuate-live parameter. * Update live migration start and monitor code. * Add database migration. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added as required. Documentation Impact ==================== New API needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html * nova.compute.api documentation http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.compute.api.html References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/305425/ History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Copy/remove the strongswan.d config as root

The strongswan.d config dir (usually /etc/strongswan.d) is usually owned
by root but the neutron-vpn-agent may run as non-root so the files need
to be copied as root to not get a "permission denied" error.

Change-Id: I40785f8c89b304efdf0f95469ec5a2d57b0cad60
Closes-Bug: #1586986

commit_message:
Coho Data: Reconnect to cluster on broken pipe

Handle broken pipe errors and retry connection to cluster
before reporting error on the operation.

Closes-Bug: #1579933

Change-Id: I681ead674f1134810ca3149ea998da027363a677
Signed-off-by: Bardia Keyoumarsi <bardia.keyoumarsi@cohodata.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/82/318382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errnoimport threadingfrom cinder.coordination import LockCOHO_MAX_RETRIES = 5 self.lock = threading.Lock() with self.lock: for retry in range(COHO_MAX_RETRIES): try: self._make_call(proc, args) break except socket.error as e: if e.errno == errno.EPIPE: # Reopen connection to cluster and retry self.init_socket() else: msg = (_('Unable to send requests: %s') % six.text_type(e)) raise exception.CohoException(msg) else: msg = _('Failed to establish a stable connection') raise exception.CohoException(msg) res = self.unpacker.unpack_uint() if res != SUCCESS: raise exception.CohoException(os.strerror(res))
deleted_lines: self._make_call(proc, args) res = self.unpacker.unpack_uint() if res != SUCCESS: raise exception.CohoException(os.strerror(res))

commit_message:
Remove integrated jobs from neutron-fwaas project config

The neutron integrated jobs (gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full and
gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron) are still configured to run with fwaas
(and lbaas) extension, however the decoupling is  ongoing (as
shown in [1]).

Running these jobs on fwaas changes is not only wasteful but it
will eventually not provide any test coverage, so they can be
removed.

[1] Ic60cd1fa90c19dfac00be583e2ddc5633dbb68a3

Change-Id: Id7c6af8d52a779ca0861970333d4c45d89aee566

Change-Id: Ifce4ce7c2ab2fa71a70d6d9028e6a60fc495d0ae
'}]
commit_message:
Copy edit feature classification

Copy edit the feature classification document
to improve language and structure.

Change-Id: Ifce4ce7c2ab2fa71a70d6d9028e6a60fc495d0ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/323655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This document defines the description features listed in theUsers want reliable, long-term solutions for their use cases. It benefits users and developers when clear expectations exist for a project's features. We take two approaches to communicating these expectations: * Tell users what features are complete, well-documented, and are kept stable by good tests. Users will have a good experience using these features. .. note:: Tests are specific to particular combinations of technologies. A deployment's choice of storage, networking, and hypervisor may affect feature functionality. * Improve features that are not in the above state and warn users about the risks of using those features before they are ready. We encourage users to provide feedback on these features.This document uses the following terminology.These are the users we talk about in this document: application deployer creates and deletes servers, directly or indirectly using an API application developer creates images and apps that run on the cloud cloud operator administers the cloud self service administrator runs and uses the cloud .. note:: This is not an exhaustive list of personas, but rather an indicative set of users.Each group maps to a set of user stories that can be validated by a set of scenarios and tests. Typically, this means a set of tempest tests. This list focuses on API concepts like attach and detach volumes, rather than deployment specific concepts like attach an iSCSI volume to a KVM based VM.A deployment maps to a specific test environment. We provide a full description of the environment, so it is possible to reproduce the reported test results for each of the Feature Groups. This description includes all aspects of the deployment, for example the hypervisor, number of nova-compute services, storage, network driver, and types of images being tested... note:: Although having some similarities, this list is not directly related to the DefCore effort. **Feature Group ratings:** Incomplete Incomplete features are those that do not have enough functionality to satisfy real world use cases. Experimental Experimental features should be used with extreme caution. They are likely to have little or no upstream testing, and are therefore likely to contain bugs. Complete For a feature to be considered complete, it must have: * complete API docs (concept and REST call definition) * complete Administrator docs * tempest tests that define if the feature works correctly * sufficient functionality and reliability to be useful in real world scenarios * a reasonable expectation that the feature will be supported long-term Complete and Required There are various reasons why a complete feature may be required, but generally it is when all drivers support that feature. New drivers need to prove they support all required features before they are allowed in upstream Nova. Required features are those that any new technology must support before being allowed into tree. The larger the list, the more features are available on all Nova based clouds. Deprecated Deprecated features are those that are scheduled to be removed in a future major release of Nova. If a feature is marked as complete, it should never be deprecated. If a feature is incomplete or experimental for several releases, it runs the risk of being deprecated and later removed from the code base.The deployment rating refers to the state of the tests for each**Deployment ratings:** Unknown No data is available. Not Implemented No tests exist. Implemented Self declared that the tempest tests pass. Regularly Tested Tested by third party CI. Checked Tested as part of the check or gate queue. The eventual goal is to automate this list from a third party CI reporting system, but currently we document manual inspections in an ini file. Ideally, we will review the list at every milestone... note:: This is still a work in progress! **Key TODOs:**
deleted_lines: This document aims to define how we describe features listed in theOur users want the features they rely on to be reliable and always continue to solve for their use case. When things break, users request that we solve their issues quickly. It would be better if we never had those regressions in the first place. We are taking a two-pronged approach: * Tell our users what features are complete, well-documented, and are kept stable by good tests. They will get a good experience if they stick to using those features. Please note that the tests are specific to particular combinations of technologies. A deployment's choice of storage, networking and hypervisor makes a big difference to what features will work. * Get help for the features that are not in the above state, and warn our users about the risks of using those features before they are ready. It should make it much clearer how to help improve the feature.Some definitions to help understand the later part of the document.These are the users we will talk about in this document: * application deployer: creates/deletes servers, directly or indirect via API * application developer: creates images and apps that run on the cloud * cloud operator: administers the cloud * self service administrator: both runs and uses the cloud Now in reality the picture is way more complex. Specifically, there are likely to be different roles for observer, creator and admin roles for the application developer. Similarly, there are likely to be various levels of cloud operator permissions, some read only, see a subset of tenants, etc. Note: this is not attempting to be an exhaustive set of personas that consider various facets of the different users, but instead aims to be a minimal set of users, such that we use a consistent terminology throughout this document.Each group maps to a set of user stories, that can be validated by a set of scenarios, tests. Typically, this means a set of tempest tests. This list focuses on API concepts like attach and detach volumes, rather than deployment specific concepts like attach iSCSI volume to KVM based VM.A deployment maps to a specific test environment. A full description of the environment should be provided, so its possible to reproduce the test results that are reported for each of the Feature Groups. Note: this description includes all aspects of the deployment: the hypervisor, the number of nova-compute services, the storage being used, the network driver being used, the types of images being tested, etc.We are starting out these Feature Group ratings: * Incomplete * Experimental * Complete * Complete and Required * Deprecated (scheduled to be removed in a future release) Incomplete features are those that don't have enough functionality to satisfy real world use cases. Experimental features should be used with extreme caution. They are likely to have little or no upstream testing. With little testing there are likely to be many unknown bugs. For a feature to be considered complete, we must have: * Complete API docs (concept and REST call definition) * Complete Administrator docs * Tempest tests that define if the feature works correctly * Has enough functionality, and works reliably enough to be useful in real world scenarios * Unlikely to ever have a reason to drop support for the feature There are various reasons why a feature, once complete, becomes required, but currently its largely when a feature is supported by all drivers. Note that any new drivers need to prove they support all required features before it would be allowed in upstream Nova. Please note that this list is technically unrelated to the DefCore effort, despite there being obvious parallels that could be drawn. Required features are those that any new technology must support before being allowed into tree. The larger the list, the more features can be expected to be available on all Nova based clouds. Deprecated features are those that are scheduled to be removed in a future major release of Nova. If a feature is marked as complete, it should never be deprecated. If a feature is incomplete or experimental for several releases, it runs the risk of being deprecated, and later removed from the code base.The deployment rating is purely about the state of the tests for eachThere will the following ratings: * unknown * not implemented * implemented: self declare the tempest tests pass * regularly tested: tested by third party CI * checked: Tested as part of the check or gate queue The eventual goal is to automate this list from some third party CI reporting system, but so we can make progress, this will be a manual inspection that is documented by an hand written ini file. Ideally, this will be reviewed every milestone.Please note: this is still a work in progress! Key TODOs:
